{{#compare sprout.custom.mode "==" "caregiver"}}

{{#i18n "caregiver_checklist"}}Personalized Checklist for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}'s Caregiver{{/i18n}}

Thank you very much for taking the time to complete the Down Syndrome Clinic to You (DSC2U) intake form. We used your responses to create this personalized checklist of information, resources, and recommendations for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}. To find out why certain suggestions were made, please click on the "Why?" link after each recommendation. The "Why" after each recommendation will explain why each suggestion was made for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}.

We know {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s health and wellness are very important to you, and we hope these resources will be helpful as you oversee {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} care. At the same time, a long list can sometimes feel a bit overwhelming. We encourage you to talk through the contents of this checklist with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s primary care provider and other trusted caregivers or family members who may help you with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s care.

The suggestions in this checklist were generated by a computer, based on your answers to the DSC2U intake form. The checklist was not prepared or reviewed by a clinician specifically for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} but was assembled from information that was carefully chosen by a team of medical experts. Whenever possible, the information in this document was drawn from national healthcare guidelines for people with Down syndrome. The information has been reviewed to make sure it is consistent with current best practices.

As a reminder, this checklist does not establish a health care provider-patient relationship. It is not an attempt to practice medicine or provide specific clinical advice. It is intended to provide useful information to you and {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s primary care provider for reference and educational purposes only. The content of this checklist is not meant to be complete or absolute or to be a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. It should not be used to make a diagnosis or to replace or overrule a qualified health care provider's judgment.

While you and your primary care provider will not have the opportunity to discuss clinical or personal information about {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} with physicians at Massachusetts General Hospital, we would be happy to answer any technical questions about DSC2U at dsc2u@mgh.harvard.edu.

We have done our best to identify the best information and resources currently available for people with Down syndrome and to try to select it in a way that could be helpful for you and your loved one. We very much hope that you find this information empowering so that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} can continue to have a healthy, meaningful, and satisfying life.

With all good wishes,

The DSC2U team


You might choose to check each item when completed for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}.

{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_moyamoya "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_leukemia "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_infantile_spasms "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_urgent_cspine "1") )}}

Urgent Suggestions for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}

It is recommended that you do NOT wait for the next scheduled routine physical exam. It is recommended that you contact {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s doctor urgently to discuss the following suggestions:

{{/if}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">" "4"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.cspine.value "==" "0"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_aai.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_cspine "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Cervical X-ray (“C-spine”). You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.torticollis.value "==" "1"}}{{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} head staying tilted to one side{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.ability_change.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.neck_pain.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.walk_change.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.new_weakness.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.arms_hands.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.accidents_urine.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.ability_change.value "==" "1"}}a decrease in activity or overall functioning{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.neck_pain.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.walk_change.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.new_weakness.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.arms_hands.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.accidents_urine.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.neck_pain.value "==" "1"}}neck pain{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.walk_change.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.new_weakness.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.arms_hands.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.accidents_urine.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.walk_change.value "==" "1"}}changes in how {{pcori_dsp_interventi.heshe}} walks{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.new_weakness.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.arms_hands.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.accidents_urine.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.new_weakness.value "==" "1"}}new weakness in one or more limbs{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.arms_hands.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.accidents_urine.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.arms_hands.value "==" "1"}}changes in how {{pcori_dsp_interventi.heshe}} uses arms or hands{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.accidents_urine.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.accidents_urine.value "==" "1"}}new accidents with urine{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "==" "1"}}new accidents with stool.{{/compare}} These could be symptoms for a condition called atlantoaxial instability (AAI), which is a weakness of the ligaments of the neck that could impact the spinal cord. You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has not had a cervical neck X-ray within the past two months. We recommend discussing a cervical X-ray immediately with a doctor. Treatment options and precautions are available for people with Down syndrome and AAI. More information on atlantoaxial instability in this webinar [video] (cue up to 09:55). {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}

pcori_dsp_interventi.arms_hands.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.accidents_urine.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare These could be symptoms for a condition called atlantoaxial instability (AAI), which is a weakness of the ligaments of the neck that could impact the spinal cord. Also, you indicated that you are not sure whether or not {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has not had a cervical X-ray (neck X-ray) within the past two months. We recommend discussing a cervical X-ray immediately with a doctor. Treatment options and precautions are available for people with Down syndrome and AAI. pcori_dsp_interventi.arms_hands.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.accidents_urine.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.arms_hands.value "==" "1"}}changes in how {{pcori_dsp_interventi.heshe}} uses arms or hands{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.accidents_urine.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.accidents_urine.value "==" "1"}}new accidents with urine{{#compare These could be symptoms for ongoing atlantoaxial instability (AAI). Also, you indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} does have a past medical history of atlanto-axial instability. Since {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has not had a cervical X-ray within the last two months, talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about getting a new cervical x-ray to check for any new changes or worsening AAI. Brain MRI (imaging). You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.new_weakness.value "==" "1"}}new weakness in one or more limbs{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.seizures.value "==" "1"}} and {{/compare}}{{/compare}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.seizures.value "==" "1"}}uncontrollable shaking of arms and legs{{/compare}}, which could be symptoms of moyamoya, a condition that affects the blood vessels in the brain in people with Down syndrome younger than 10 years of age. Today, treatment options are available for children with Down syndrome and moyamoya. More information on moyamoya in children. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "6"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_all.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_aml.value "!=" "1"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.fever.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.limp.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

CBC with differential (blood work). You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.fever.value "==" "1"}}fever that hasn't gone away in at least five days{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.limp.value "==" "1"}} and {{/compare}}{{/compare}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.limp.value "==" "1"}}a new limp{{/compare}}, which could be symptoms for leukemia in people with Down syndrome younger than 6 years of age. Today, treatment options are available for children with Down syndrome and leukemia. More information on blood testing for leukemia in children with Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age_months "<=" "15"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_seizures.value "!=" "1"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.infantile_spasms.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.infantile_spasms2.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

EEG (electroencephalogram). You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.infantile_spasms.value "==" "1"}}abnormal facial grimaces{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.infantile_spasms2.value "==" "1"}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.infantile_spasms3.value "==" "1"}},{{else}} and {{/compare}}{{else}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.infantile_spasms3.value "==" "1"}} and {{else}},{{/compare}}{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.infantile_spasms2.value "==" "1"}}jerking of arms or legs{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.infantile_spasms3.value "==" "1"}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.infantile_spasms.value "==" "1"}},{{/compare}} and {{else}},{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.infantile_spasms3.value "==" "1"}}staring episodes,{{/compare}} which could be symptoms for infantile spasms in children with Down syndrome younger than 15 months of age. Today, treatment options are available for children with Down syndrome and infantile spasms. More information on infantile spasms in infants with Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}}

Labs, Tests, and Procedures for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}

It is recommended that you ask {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}'s doctor to consider ordering the following during the upcoming routine physical exam:

{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.audio_12m.value "==" "0"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<=" "6"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Audiogram/hearing test. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} is due for a hearing test. More information on hearing loss and Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Evaluation and treatment options [video]. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Up to 75 of every 100 Individuals with Down syndrome have hearing loss; the American Academy of Pediatrics recommends all individuals have an audiogram every 6 months until hearing is confirmed in both ears. At that point, hearing tests can be spaced to annual exams. You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} did not have an audiogram within the past year.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.audio_12m.value "==" "0"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">" "6"}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Up to 75 of every 100 individuals with Down syndrome have hearing loss; the American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that children with Down syndrome have an audiogram every 6 months until hearing is confirmed in both ears, and then an audiogram once every year after that until age 21. {{/if}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiac_test.value "==" "999"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_celiac1 "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_celiac2 "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Celiac screen (blood work). {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has symptoms that might be consistent with celiac disease [video] {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. Further testing is needed {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}, with potential follow-up testing {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. Treatment options are available for those with a confirmed diagnosis (brief handout {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} and more information on gluten-free foods {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}). {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

learned skills.{{/compare}} These symptoms could be consistent with celiac disease. You are also not sure whether {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has ever had celiac testing done. You should discuss this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider and consider testing if bloodwork has not been done within the past 12 months.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiac_test.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiac_time.value "==" "0"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiacd.value "!=" "1"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_celiac1 "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_celiac2 "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Celiac screen (blood work). {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has symptoms that might be consistent with celiac disease [video] {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. Further testing is needed {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}, with potential follow-up testing {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. Treatment options are available for those with a confirmed diagnosis (brief handout {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} and more information on gluten-free foods {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}). {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation.value "==" "1"}}constipation that is hard to treat{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.diarrhea.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.nausea.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.vomiting.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.stool.value "1") {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.aggression.value "==" "1"}}aggression{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.property_destruction.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.cries_easily.value "1") (eq easily or for no reason{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "==" "1"}}loss of previously learned skills.{{/compare}} These symptoms could be consistent with celiac disease, which can emerge at any point during the lifetime of someone with Down syndrome. You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has not had celiac testing done within the past 12 months.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiac_test.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiac_time.value "==" "0"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiacd.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.gluten_free.value "==" "1"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_celiac1 "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_celiac2 "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Celiac screen (blood work) because {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} might still have some unknown sources of gluten remaining in {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} diet. You might also find this video {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}, brief handout {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}, and more information on gluten-free foods {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to be helpful. Also, you can find a wealth of resources from CeliacNow {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation.value "==" "1"}}constipation that is hard to treat{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.diarrhea.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.nausea.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.vomiting.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.stool.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.flatulence.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.bloating.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.ftt.value "1") )}}, {{else}}{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hyperactivity_adhd.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.inattention.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.impulsivity.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.distracted.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.uncooperative.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.temper_meltdowns_irritability.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hits_self.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.bites_self.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.injures_self.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.bangs_head.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.irritable.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hits_others.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.mood_swings.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.aggression.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.property_destruction.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.cries_easily.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.diarrhea.value "==" "1"}}frequent diarrhea{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.nausea.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.vomiting.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.stool.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.flatulence.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.bloating.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.ftt.value "1") )}}, {{else}}{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hyperactivity_adhd.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.inattention.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.impulsivity.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.distracted.value "1") (eq {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.aggression.value "==" "1"}}aggression{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.property_destruction.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.cries_easily.value "1") (eq easily or for no reason{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "==" "1"}}loss of previously learned skills.{{/compare}} You also indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has a diagnosis of celiac disease and is on a gluten-free diet. Since {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has not had celiac testing done within the past 12 months, you should talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s doctor about using the celiac screen to see if any gluten might still be remaining in {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} diet.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "4"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "18"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep_study.value "==" "0"}} {{#if (and (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_apnea "1") (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_depression "1") (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_anxiety "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Sleep study. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has never had a sleep study. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that all children with Down syndrome have a sleep study. {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Testing for sleep apnea is important {{#es}}[Español] {{/es}}{{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} with many medical consequences if apnea is present and untreated [video] {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Here is how caregivers can prepare for sleep studies{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Here is a social story that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} can use prepare for the sleep study{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Of every 100 people with Down syndrome, up to 75 are expected to have obstructive sleep apnea, while 25 do not. Research has also shown that patients with Down syndrome may lose up to 9 IQ points within a year when their apnea is untreated. Since {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} hasn’t had a sleep study yet, you should discuss this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s doctor.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "18"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep_study.value "==" "0"}} {{#if (and (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_apnea "1") (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_depression "1") (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_anxiety "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Sleep study. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has never had a sleep study. Experts recommend that all individuals with Down syndrome have at least one sleep study. {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Testing for sleep apnea is important {{#es}}[Español] {{/es}}{{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} with many medical consequences if apnea is present and untreated [video] {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. Treatment options are available for those with a confirmed diagnosis. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Here is how caregivers can prepare for sleep studies{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Here is a social story that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} can use prepare for the sleep study. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Of every 100 people with Down syndrome, up to 75 are expected to have obstructive sleep apnea, while 25 do not. Research has also shown that patients with Down syndrome may lose up to 9 IQ points within one year when their apnea is untreated. Since {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} hasn’t had a sleep study yet, you should discuss this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s doctor.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "18"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep_study.value "==" "0"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_apnea "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_depression "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_anxiety "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Sleep study. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has symptoms that might be consistent with obstructive sleep apnea. Further testing is needed. {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Testing for sleep apnea is important {{#es}}[Español] {{/es}}{{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} with many medical consequences if apnea is present and untreated [video] {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.snore.value "==" "1"}}snoring{{#if (or (eq {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "==" "1"}}feeling tense, anxious, worried{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "==" "1"}}distress about being alone.{{/compare}} Also, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has never had a sleep study. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that everyone with Down syndrome be evaluated for obstructive sleep apnea if symptoms, such as these, arise. A sleep study is the best way to assess for obstructive sleep apnea. Of every 100 people with Down syndrome, up to 75 are expected to have sleep apnea and 25 will not. Research has also shown that patients with Down syndrome may lose up to 9 IQ points within a year when their apnea is untreated.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "18"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep_study.value "==" "0"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_apnea "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_depression "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_anxiety "1") )}}

{{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "==" "1"}}feeling tense, anxious, worried{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "==" "1"}}distress about being alone.{{/compare}} Also, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has never had a sleep study. Experts recommend that everyone with Down syndrome be evaluated for obstructive sleep apnea if symptoms, such as these, arise. A sleep study is the best way to assess for obstructive sleep apnea. Of every 100 people with Down syndrome, up to 75 are expected to have sleep apnea and 25 will not. Research has also shown that patients with Down syndrome may lose up to 9 IQ points within a year when their apnea is untreated.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "4"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "18"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep_study.value "==" "999"}} {{#if (and (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_apnea "1") (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_depression "1") (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_anxiety "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Sleep study. You said that you are unsure if {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has ever had a sleep study. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that all children with Down syndrome have a sleep study. {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Testing for sleep apnea is important {{#es}}[Español] {{/es}}{{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} with many medical consequences if apnea is present and untreated [video] {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. Treatment options are available for those with a confirmed diagnosis. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Here is how caregivers can prepare for sleep studies{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Here is a social story that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} can use prepare for the sleep study{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Of every 100 people with Down syndrome, up to 75 are expected to have obstructive sleep apnea, while 25 do not. Research has also shown that patients with Down syndrome may lose up to 9 IQ points within a year when their apnea is untreated. Since {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} may not have had a sleep study yet, you should discuss this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s doctor.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "18"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep_study.value "==" "999"}} {{#if (and (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_apnea "1") (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_depression "1") (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_anxiety "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Sleep study. You said that you are unsure if {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has ever had a sleep study. Experts recommend that all individuals with Down syndrome have at least one sleep study. {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Testing for sleep apnea is important {{#es}}[Español] {{/es}}{{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} with many medical consequences if apnea is present and untreated [video] {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. Treatment options are available for those with a confirmed diagnosis. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Here is how caregivers can prepare for sleep studies{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Here is a social story that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} can use prepare for the sleep study. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Of every 100 people with Down syndrome, up to 75 are expected to have obstructive sleep apnea, while 25 do not. Research has also shown that patients with Down syndrome may lose up to 9 IQ points within a year when their apnea is untreated. Since {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} may not have had a sleep study yet, you should discuss this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s doctor.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "18"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep_study.value "==" "999"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_apnea "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_depression "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_anxiety "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Sleep study. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has symptoms that might be consistent with obstructive sleep apnea. Further testing is needed. {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Testing for sleep apnea is important {{#es}}[Español] {{/es}}{{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} with many medical consequences if apnea is present and untreated [video] {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. easily or for no reason{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.moves_slow.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.eat.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.moves_slow.value "==" "1"}}moving slowly{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.eat.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "==" "1"}}loss of previously learned skills{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.eat.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.eat.value "==" "1"}}eating too much or too little{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "==" "1"}}trouble falling asleep or staying asleep{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "==" "1"}}feeling tense, anxious, worried{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "==" "1"}}distress about being alone.{{/compare}} Also, you indicated that you are not sure whether or not {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has ever had a sleep study. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that everyone with Down syndrome be evaluated for obstructive sleep apnea if symptoms, such as these, arise. A sleep study is the best way to assess for obstructive sleep apnea. Of every 100 people with Down syndrome, up to 75 are expected to have sleep apnea and 25 will not. Research has also shown that patients with Down syndrome may lose up to 9 IQ points within a year when their apnea is untreated.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "18"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep_study.value "==" "999"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_apnea "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_depression "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_anxiety "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Sleep study. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has symptoms that might be consistent with obstructive sleep apnea. Further testing is needed. {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Testing for sleep apnea is important {{#es}}[Español] {{/es}}{{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} with many medical consequences if apnea is present and untreated [video] {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. Treatment options are available for those with a confirmed diagnosis. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Here is how caregivers can prepare for sleep studies{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Here is a social story that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} can use prepare for the sleep study. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.snore.value "==" "1"}}snoring{{#if (or (eq {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "==" "1"}}distress about being alone.{{/compare}} Also, you indicated that you are not sure whether or not {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has ever had a sleep study. Experts recommend that everyone with Down syndrome be evaluated for obstructive sleep apnea if symptoms, such as these, arise. A sleep study is the best way to assess for obstructive sleep apnea. Of every 100 people with Down syndrome, up to 75 are expected to have sleep apnea and 25 will not. Research has also shown that patients with Down syndrome may lose up to 9 IQ points within a year when their apnea is untreated.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "18"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "4"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep_study.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.polysom_time.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.osa.value "!=" "1"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_apnea "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_depression "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_anxiety "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Sleep study. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has symptoms that might be consistent with obstructive sleep apnea. Given how common sleep apnea is in people with Down syndrome, another sleep study is recommended since it has been more than 12 months since {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has had one done. {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Testing for sleep apnea is important {{#es}}[Español] {{/es}}{{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} with many medical consequences if apnea is present and untreated [video] {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. Treatment options are available for those with a confirmed diagnosis. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Here is how caregivers can prepare for sleep studies{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Here is a social story that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} can use prepare for the sleep study{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.snore.value "==" "1"}}snoring{{#if (or (eq {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "==" "1"}}distress about being alone.{{/compare}} {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has not had a sleep study within the past 12 months. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that everyone with Down syndrome be evaluated for obstructive sleep apnea annually if symptoms, such as these, arise. A sleep study is the best way to assess for obstructive sleep apnea. Of every 100 people with Down syndrome, up to 75 are expected to have sleep apnea and 25 will not. Research has also shown that patients with Down syndrome may lose up to 9 IQ points within a year when their apnea is untreated.

{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

(eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "==" "1"}}loss of previously learned skills{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.eat.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.eat.value "==" "1"}}eating too much or too little{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "==" "1"}}trouble falling asleep or staying asleep{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "==" "1"}}feeling tense, anxious, worried{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "==" "1"}}distress about being alone.{{/compare}} {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has not had a sleep study within the past 12 months. Experts recommend that everyone with Down syndrome be evaluated for obstructive sleep apnea annually if symptoms, such as these, arise. A sleep study is the best way to assess for obstructive sleep apnea. Of every 100 people with Down syndrome, up to 75 are expected to have sleep apnea and 25 will not. Research has also shown that patients with Down syndrome may lose up to 9 IQ points within a year when their apnea is untreated.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.thyroid_test.value "==" "0"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Thyroid function tests (blood work). {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} is due for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} thyroid check. Further testing is needed. Treatment options are available for those with a confirmed diagnosis [video]. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} More information on thyroid conditions in Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past 12 months, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has not had {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} thyroid levels drawn. Individuals with Down syndrome have a significant risk of developing thyroid problems, which are important to treat. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that everyone with Down syndrome have thyroid levels checked annually.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.thyroid_test.value "==" "0"}}

Thyroid function tests (blood work). Although {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has had {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} annual thyroid bloodwork, repeat testing may be needed based on {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s current symptoms. Treatment options are available for those with a confirmed diagnosis [video]. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} More information on thyroid conditions in Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

easily or for no reason{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.moves_slow.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.eat.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.moves_slow.value "==" "1"}}moving slowly{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.eat.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "==" "1"}}loss of previously learned skills{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.eat.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.eat.value "==" "1"}}eating too much or too little{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "==" "1"}}trouble falling asleep or staying asleep{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "==" "1"}}feeling tense, anxious, worried{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "==" "1"}}distress about being alone{{/compare}} These may be suggestive of hypothyroidism, a condition where the thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormone. This is common in patients with Down syndrome and treatment is available if a diagnosis is confirmed. Experts recommend that everyone with Down syndrome have their thyroid levels checked once annually, but since {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} is experiencing these symptoms, you should discuss them with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider and perhaps repeating the testing sooner.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.thyroid_test.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_hypothyroid "==" "1"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_hashimotos.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_hypothyroidism.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Thyroid function tests (blood work). Although {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has had {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} annual thyroid bloodwork, repeat testing may be needed based on {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s current symptoms. {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.meds_hash.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.meds_hypo.value "1") )}} {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s medications may need to be adjusted. {{/if}} More information on thyroid conditions in Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

hormone. {{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Thyroid function tests (blood work). Although {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} had {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} annual thyroid check, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.heshe}} has a past diagnosis of thyroid disease. We suggest discussing repeat thyroid testing with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider to see if {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s thyroid medication dosage needs to be adjusted. You mentioned several symptoms that could be related to thyroid imbalance. Treatment options are available for those with a confirmed diagnosis [video]. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} More information on thyroid conditions in Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has had symptoms such as {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.too_hot.value "==" "1"}}feeling too hot{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.weight_loss.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.diarrhea.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.irregular_menstruation.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.ritualistic_behaviors_ocd.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.obsessive_thoughts.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hyperactivity_adhd.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.weight_loss.value "==" "1"}}undesired weight loss{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.diarrhea.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.irregular_menstruation.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.ritualistic_behaviors_ocd.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.obsessive_thoughts.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hyperactivity_adhd.value "1") (eq {{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Thyroid function tests (blood work). Although {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} had {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} annual thyroid check, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.heshe}} has a past diagnosis of thyroid disease and is not on medication for it. We suggest discussing repeat thyroid testing with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider to see if medication would be appropriate. You mentioned several symptoms that could be related to thyroid imbalance. Treatment options are available for those with a confirmed diagnosis [video]. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} More information on thyroid conditions in Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has had symptoms such as {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.too_hot.value "==" "1"}}feeling too hot{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.weight_loss.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.diarrhea.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.irregular_menstruation.value "1") (eq {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.situation_fear.value "==" "1"}}fear of particular situations.{{/compare}} You also indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has a past medical history of {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_graves.value "==" "1"}}Graves disease{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_hyperthyroidism.value "==" "1"}} and {{/compare}}{{/compare}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_hyperthyroidism.value "==" "1"}}hyperthyroidism{{/compare}} and is not on any medication for it.
{{/if}} {{/if}} {{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_anemia.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hgb.value "==" "0"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Hemoglobin level (blood work). {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} is due for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} check for anemia. Further testing is needed. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Treatment options may include increasing iron in the diet {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} or starting an iron supplement. Your provider might order a complete blood count (rather than just a hemoglobin level). If so, don’t be alarmed if some of the values are slightly abnormal. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Children with Down syndrome are at risk of developing iron-deficiency anemia, which means that their hemoglobin, which is how oxygen is transported in our bodies, is low because the body isn’t receiving enough iron to make the hemoglobin. Anemia can also affect cognitive function. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends testing the hemoglobin level every year, which will tell us whether or not anemia is present. If this is the case, your provider may consider adding iron to your diet, through diet or supplements, which helps resolve the anemia.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_anemia.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hgb.value "==" "0"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Hemoglobin level (blood work). You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} already has a diagnosis of anemia but has not had {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} blood work checked in the past year. Further testing is needed {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to monitor the anemia and adjust treatment options. Here are some ways to increase iron in the diet. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Your provider might also prescribe or adjust iron supplements. Your provider might order a complete blood count (rather than just a hemoglobin level). If so, don’t be alarmed if some of the values are slightly abnormal. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Children with Down syndrome are at risk of developing iron-deficiency anemia, which means that their hemoglobin, which is how oxygen is transported in our bodies, is low because the body isn’t receiving enough iron to make the hemoglobin. Anemia can also affect cognitive function. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends testing the hemoglobin level every year, which will tell us whether or not anemia is present and, if so, whether treatment or dietary options need to be adjusted. If this is the case, your provider may consider adding iron to your diet, through diet or supplements, which helps resolve the anemia.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_anemia.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hgb.value "==" "999"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Hemoglobin level (blood work). You indicated that you are not sure whether {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has had a hemoglobin tested in the past 12 months. Further testing is needed. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} If {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} is found to have anemia, treatment options may include increasing iron in the diet {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} or starting an iron supplement. Your provider might order a complete blood count (rather than just a hemoglobin level). If so, don’t be alarmed if some of the values are slightly abnormal. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Children with Down syndrome are at risk of developing iron-deficiency anemia, which means that their hemoglobin, which is how oxygen is transported in our bodies, is low because the body isn’t receiving enough iron to make the hemoglobin. Anemia can also affect cognitive function. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends testing the hemoglobin level every year, which will tell us whether or not anemia is present. If this is the case, your provider may consider adding iron to your diet, through diet or supplements, which helps resolve the anemia.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_anemia.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hgb.value "==" "999"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Hemoglobin level (blood work). You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} already has a diagnosis of anemia but you are not sure if {{pcori_dsp_interventi.heshe}} had {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} blood work checked in the past year. Further testing is needed {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to monitor the anemia and adjust treatment options. Here are some ways to increase iron in the diet. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Your provider might also prescribe or adjust iron supplements. Your provider might order a complete blood count (rather than just a hemoglobin level). If so, don’t be alarmed if some of the values are slightly abnormal. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Children with Down syndrome are at risk of developing iron-deficiency anemia, which means that their hemoglobin, which is how oxygen is transported in our bodies, is low because the body isn’t receiving enough iron to make the hemoglobin. Anemia can also affect cognitive function. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends testing the hemoglobin level every year, which will tell us whether or not anemia is present and, if so, whether treatment or dietary options need to be adjusted. If this is the case, your provider may consider adding iron to your diet, through diet or supplements, which helps resolve the anemia.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.vfss.value "==" "0"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.conc_cough.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.aspiration_liquids.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Video Fluoroscopic Swallowing Study (swallowing X-ray). {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has symptoms that may suggest impaired swallowing. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider to see if a swallowing x-ray might be helpful for further evaluation. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has had symptoms such as {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.conc_cough.value "==" "1"}}coughing when eating solid foods{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.aspiration_liquids.value "==" "1"}} and {{/compare}}{{/compare}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.aspiration_liquids.value "==" "1"}}coughing, choking, or throat clearing while drinking{{/compare}}. This may be because {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s swallowing is impaired, and this might put {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} at risk for lung infections caused by food or drink ending up in the airways. Since {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has not had a swallowing x-ray in the past 12 months, we recommend talking to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about getting a swallowing study or seeing a swallow therapist to assess the function of {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s swallowing.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.vfss.value "==" "999"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.conc_cough.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.aspiration_liquids.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Video Fluoroscopic Swallowing Study (swallowing X-ray). {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has symptoms that may suggest impaired swallowing. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider to see if a swallowing x-ray might be helpful for further evaluation. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has had symptoms such as {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.conc_cough.value "==" "1"}}coughing when eating solid foods{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.aspiration_liquids.value "==" "1"}} and {{/compare}}{{/compare}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.aspiration_liquids.value "==" "1"}}coughing, choking, or throat clearing while drinking{{/compare}}. This may be because {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s swallowing is impaired, and this might put {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} at risk for lung infections caused by food or drink ending up in the airways. Since you indicated that you are not sure whether or not {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has had a swallowing x-ray in the past 12 months, we recommend talking to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about getting a swallowing study or seeing a swallow therapist to assess the function of {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s swallowing.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_dementia.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_dementia "==" "1"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.vfss.value "0") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.vfss.value "999") )}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.weight_loss.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_aspiration.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Video Fluoroscopic Swallowing Study (swallowing X-ray). {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has symptoms that suggest impaired swallowing. A swallowing x-ray will determine the need for further evaluation. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has had symptoms such as {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.weight_loss.value "==" "1"}}weight loss{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "==" "1"}}general agitation.{{/compare}} This may be because {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s swallowing is impaired as a part of possible Alzheimer’s disease (dementia). This puts {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} at risk for lung infections caused by food or drink ending up in the airways. Since you indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has not had a swallowing x-ray in the past 12 months, we recommend talking to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about getting one to assess the function of {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s swallowing.

Video Fluoroscopic Swallowing Study (swallowing X-ray). {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has symptoms that suggest impaired swallowing. A swallowing x-ray will determine the need for further evaluation. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.colonca_screening.value "==" "0"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Colon cancer screening. Testing might not necessarily be needed, but further discussion with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider is suggested. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has never been screened for colon cancer. Research has demonstrated that colon cancer is less common in adults with Down syndrome. We recommend discussing this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider, particularly if there is a family history of colon cancer or other risk factors.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.colonca_screening.value "==" "999"}}

Research has demonstrated that breast cancer is less common in adults with Down syndrome. We recommend discussing this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider, particularly if there is a family history of breast cancer or other risk factors.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pap_smear.value "==" "0"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Pap smear. We recommend discussing this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has never had a Pap smear. There is a very low risk of developing cervical cancer in the absence of having sexual intercourse. Nonetheless, experts specializing in Down syndrome recommend that adult women with Down syndrome consider having a Pap smear, particularly if they are sexually active. Performing a Pap smear on an adult woman who has not had sexual intercourse can be challenging and would be unlikely to provide benefit.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pap_smear.value "==" "999"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Pap Smear. We recommend discussing this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that you were not sure if {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has ever had a Pap smear. There is a very low risk of developing cervical cancer in the absence of having sexual intercourse. Nonetheless, experts specializing in Down syndrome recommend that adult women with Down syndrome consider having a Pap smear, particularly if they are sexually active. Performing a Pap smear on an adult woman who has not had sexual intercourse can be challenging and would be unlikely to provide benefit.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.imm_influenza.value "==" "2"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Flu shot. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} gets {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} flu vaccine “most years.” Experts recommend that people with Down syndrome get their flu shots every year, the same as everyone else in the general population. If this has not been done this year, we recommend discussing this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.imm_influenza.value "==" "3"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} gets {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} flu vaccine “some years.” Experts recommend that people with Down syndrome get their flu shots every year, the same as everyone else in the general population. Flu shot. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that you are not sure how often {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} gets a flu vaccine. Experts recommend that people with Down syndrome get their flu shots every year, the same as everyone else in the general population. We recommend discussing this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.imm_pneumonia.value "==" "0"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Pneumonia vaccine. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Experts specializing in Down syndrome recommend that adults with Down syndrome receive pneumonia vaccines at an earlier age. Individuals with Down syndrome are at an increased risk of developing pneumonia due to a slightly weaker immune system. You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has not had a pneumonia vaccine in the past. We recommend discussing this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.imm_pneumonia.value "==" "999"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Pneumonia vaccine. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Experts specializing in Down syndrome recommend that adults with Down syndrome receive pneumonia vaccines at an earlier age. Individuals with Down syndrome are at an increased risk of developing pneumonia due to a slightly weaker immune system. You indicated that you are not sure whether or not {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has had a pneumonia vaccine in the past. We recommend discussing this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.imm_hpv.value "==" "0"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

HPV vaccine. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Experts specializing in Down syndrome recommend that boys and girls between the ages of 9 and 26 receive the standard three doses of the human-papilloma virus (HPV) vaccine, to protect against HPV infection, regardless of sexual activity. You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has not had an HPV vaccine in the past.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.imm_hpv.value "==" "999"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

HPV vaccine. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}Experts specializing in Down syndrome recommend that boys and girls between the ages of 9 and 26 receive the standard three doses of the human-papilloma virus (HPV) vaccine, to protect against HPV infection, regardless of sexual activity. You indicated that you are not sure whether or not {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has had an HPV vaccine in the past.
{{/compare}} {{#if (and (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.speak_ability.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.clarity_speech.value "2") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.speak_less.value "2") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

SLP referral. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about having {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} referred to a Speech and Language Pathologist or Therapist to assess {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s speaking abilities. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced a change in {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} ability to speak; seeing a speech and language therapist may help figure out why this has happened and whether or not anything can be done to help {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}.
{{/if}} {{#if (and (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.listen_ability.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.more_instruction.value "2") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.words_understand.value "2") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

SLP referral. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about having {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} referred to a Speech and Language Pathologist or Therapist to assess {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s listening abilities. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced a change in {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} ability to listen; seeing a speech and language therapist may help figure out why this has happened and whether or not anything can be done to help {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}.
{{/if}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.speak_ability.value "==" "1"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.clarity_speech.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.speak_less.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

SLP and Neuropsych referral. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about having {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} referred to a Speech and Language Pathologist and a neuropsychologist to assess {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s speaking abilities. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced a change in {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} ability to speak, and you also indicated that {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.clarity_speech.value "==" "1"}}there has been a decrease in {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}'s speaking clarity or fluency{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.speak_less.value "==" "1"}} and {{/compare}}{{/compare}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.speak_less.value "==" "1"}}{{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} is speaking less now{{/compare}}. Seeing a speech and language pathologist/therapist and a neuropsychologist may help figure out why these changes have happened and what therapies may help {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.listen_ability.value "==" "1"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.more_instruction.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.words_understand.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

SLP and Neuropsych referral. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about having {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} referred to a Speech and Language Pathologist and a neuropsychologist to assess {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s listening abilities. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced a change in {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} ability to listen, and you also indicated that {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.more_instruction.value "==" "1"}}{{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} is having more difficulty following instructions{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.words_understand.value "==" "1"}} and {{/compare}}{{/compare}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.words_understand.value "==" "1"}}{{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} is having more difficulty understanding the meaning of words{{/compare}}. Seeing a speech and language pathologist/therapist and a neuropsychologist may help figure out why these changes have happened and what therapies may help {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "20"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_gender.value "==" "M"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.testicular_pmh.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Testicular/Scrotal exam. All men with Down syndrome should be routinely screened for testicular cancer. Read page 192-193 in this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to learn more. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Most cancers are generally less common in people with Down syndrome than in the general population. However, testicular cancer can be slightly more common in men with Down syndrome. Based on what you told us, there is nothing to suggest that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has testicular cancer. We encourage routine, frequent testicular exams by {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider at each appointment, or whenever possible.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.murmur.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.poor_exercise_tolerance.value "1") )}} {{#if (and (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.asd.value "1") (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.vsd.value "1") (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.avsd.value "1") (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.pda.value "1") (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.tof.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Echocardiogram. More information on the heart in children with Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Read pages 108-109 in this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to learn more about heart conditions that can arise for the first time in adolescents and adults with Down syndrome. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that some of your current medical concerns for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} are {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.poor_exercise_tolerance.value "==" "1"}}{{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} becoming increasingly tired after exercise{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.murmur.value "==" "1"}} and {{/compare}}{{/compare}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.murmur.value "==" "1"}}a new murmur noticed by a doctor{{/compare}}. As people with Down syndrome grow older, new problems can arise with their heart valves. Experts recommend obtaining an echocardiogram (imaging of the heart) in adolescence and adulthood (even if there was a normal echocardiogram at birth) if there are new symptoms. Consider discussing this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider.
{{/if}} {{/if}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_aspiration "==" "1"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.vfss.value "0") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.vfss.value "999") )}} {{#if (and (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_dementia "1") (ne pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_dementia.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Swallowing Evaluation. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about getting a Clinical Swallow Evaluation due to problems with swallowing. Also, a swallowing X-ray (Video-fluoroscopic swallowing study) may be needed. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.chewing.value "==" "1"}}more difficulty chewing in the last year{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.drinking_aspiration.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.foodaspiration.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.regurgitate.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.pills_food.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.food_enjoyment.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.drinking_aspiration.value "==" "1"}}coughing or clearing throat while drinking{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.foodaspiration.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.regurgitate.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.pills_food.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.food_enjoyment.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.foodaspiration.value "==" "1"}}coughing or clearing throat while eating solid foods{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.regurgitate.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.pills_food.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.food_enjoyment.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.regurgitate.value "==" "1"}}regurgitating (vomiting) after eating or drinking{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.pills_food.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.food_enjoyment.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pills_food.value "==" "1"}}getting food or pills stuck in {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} throat{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.food_enjoyment.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.food_enjoyment.value "==" "1"}}a change in appetite or enjoyment of food.{{/compare}}
{{/if}} {{/if}} {{/compare}}

New or Known Conditions/Diagnoses to be considered for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}

There are many medical, behavioral, and mental health conditions that can co-occur with Down syndrome. Sometimes, it is not just Down syndrome! Proper evaluation and treatment of co-occurring conditions can result in healthier and happier lives. It is recommended that you discuss these potential conditions with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s doctor during the upcoming routine physical exam:

{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_depression.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_depression_helper1 "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Depression. Check out chapter 14 of this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to see if it fits with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s mood. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} People with Down syndrome may sometimes experience depression, but it may not be as apparent as it is in the general population. You indicated that within the past 6 months, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced a lack of interest in activities and is sad, downcast, or unhappy. These symptoms may be suggestive of depression, or there may be medical causes for these symptoms. We recommend exploring this further with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider. Treatment is available for those with a diagnosis of depression.
{{else}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_depression_helper4 "==" "1"}}

Depression. Check out chapter 14 of this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to see if it fits with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s mood. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}
