{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_ocd.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_ocd "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). Check out chapter 16 of this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to see if it fits with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s behaviors. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} People with Down syndrome may sometimes experience obsessive-compulsive disorder, which is a common mental health condition characterized by repetitive, uncontrollable, and distressing thoughts or behaviors. You indicated that within the past 6 months, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.ritualistic_behaviors_ocd.value "==" "1"}}ritualistic compulsive behaviors{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.obsessive_thoughts.value "==" 1}} and {{/compare}}{{/compare}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.obsessive_thoughts.value "==" 1}} obsessions with ideas or activities {{/compare}} and that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} finds these distressing, or they disrupt {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} daily routine. We recommend exploring this further with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider. Treatment is available for those with a diagnosis of obsessive-compulsive disorder.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_anxiety.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_anxiety "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Anxiety. Check out chapter 15 of this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to see if it fits with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s behaviors. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} People with Down syndrome may sometimes experience anxiety. You indicated that within the past 6 months, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.irritable.value "==" "1"}}irritability{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.situation_fear.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.chews_parts.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.situation_fear.value "==" "1"}}fear of particular situations{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.chews_parts.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.chews_parts.value "==" "1"}}chewing body parts{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "==" "1"}}general agitation.{{/compare}} We recommend exploring this further with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider. Treatment is available for those with a diagnosis of anxiety.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_autism "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Autism-Spectrum Disorder. Check out chapter 22 of this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to see if it fits with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s behaviors. Also, check out this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}, or watch this webinar [video] {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past six months, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} appears to {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.do_own.value "==" "1"}}prefer to do things on {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} own{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.aloof_asd.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.not_respond_feelings.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.arranges_objects.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.upset_changes_routine.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.repetitive_activity.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.aloof_asd.value "==" "1"}}be distant or aloof, in {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} own world{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.not_respond_feelings.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.arranges_objects.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.upset_changes_routine.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.repetitive_activity.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.not_respond_feelings.value "==" "1"}}not respond to others' feelings{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.arranges_objects.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.upset_changes_routine.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.repetitive_activity.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.arranges_objects.value "==" "1"}}arrange objects in a strict order{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.upset_changes_routine.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.repetitive_activity.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.upset_changes_routine.value "==" "1"}}get upset over small changes in routine{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.repetitive_activity.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.repetitive_activity.value "==" "1"}}exhibit stimming (such as rocking, pacing, or hand-flapping).{{/compare}} This may be suggestive of autism-spectrum disorder. People with Down syndrome may sometimes have a dual diagnosis of Down syndrome and autism (autism-spectrum disorder). Discuss with your primary care provider if any of the following clinicians might be helpful: a neuropsychologist, a neurologist, a developmental specialist, or a psychiatrist. If a diagnosis of autism-spectrum disorder is made, there are many additional therapies and services that can provide benefit.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_adhd.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_adhd "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Attention-Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder. Check out this webinar [video] {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} which explains the symptoms and treatment for ADHD in children with Down syndrome. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past six months, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} appears to exhibit {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hyperactivity_adhd.value "==" "1"}}overactivity, restlessness, inability to sit still{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.inattention.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.impulsivity.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.distracted.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.uncooperative.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.inattention.value "==" "1"}}inattention{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.impulsivity.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.distracted.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.uncooperative.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.impulsivity.value "==" "1"}}impulsivity, acting without thinking{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.distracted.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.uncooperative.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.distracted.value "==" "1"}}being easily distracted{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.uncooperative.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.uncooperative.value "==" "1"}}uncooperative behavior, disobedience.{{/compare}} This may be suggestive of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), which can be common in people with Down syndrome. People with this condition often have short attention spans and difficulty concentrating. Treatment is available for those with a confirmed diagnosis.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_depression.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_depression "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Depression. Check out chapter 14 of this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} for more information on depression in Down syndrome. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has a {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.confirm_depression.value "==" "1"}}suspected{{/compare}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.confirm_depression.value "==" "2"}}known{{/compare}} diagnosis of depression. You also indicated that within the past 6 months, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.sad_depression.value "==" "1"}}feeling sad, downcast, or unhappy{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.lack_interest_activities.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.cries_easily.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.moves_slow.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.eat.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.cries_easily.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.moves_slow.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.eat.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.cries_easily.value "==" "1"}}crying easily for no reason{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.moves_slow.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "1") (eq {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.moves_slow.value "==" "1"}}moving slowly{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.eat.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "==" "1"}}loss of previously learned skills{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.eat.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.eat.value "==" "1"}}eating too much or eating too little{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.sleep.value "==" "1"}}trouble falling or staying asleep{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.tense_anxiety.value "==" "1"}}feeling tense, anxious, worried{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.alone_distress.value "==" "1"}}distress about being alone.{{/compare}} These symptoms are suggestive of ongoing depression or there may be medical causes for these symptoms. We recommend exploring this further with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_anxiety.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_anxiety "==" "1"}}

Anxiety. Check out chapter 15 of this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} for more information on anxiety in Down syndrome. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

You also indicated that within the past 6 months, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.irritable.value "==" "1"}}irritability{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.situation_fear.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.chews_parts.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.situation_fear.value "==" "1"}}fear of particular situations{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.chews_parts.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.chews_parts.value "==" "1"}}chewing body parts{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "==" "1"}}general agitation.{{/compare}} These symptoms are suggestive of ongoing anxiety or there may be medical causes for these symptoms. We recommend exploring this further with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_ocd.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_ocd "==" "1"}}

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). Check out chapter 16 of this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} for more information on OCD and Down syndrome. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has a diagnosis of obsessive-compulsive disorder. You also indicated that within the past 6 months, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.ritualistic_behaviors_ocd.value "==" "1"}}ritualistic compulsive behaviors{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.obsessive_thoughts.value "==" 1}} and {{/compare}}{{/compare}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.obsessive_thoughts.value "==" 1}} obsessions with ideas or activities {{/compare}} and that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} finds these distressing, or they disrupt {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} daily routine. These symptoms are suggestive of unmanaged OCD, or there may be medical causes for these symptoms. We recommend exploring this further with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider.

Attention-Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder. Check out this resource {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} or this webinar [video] {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} for more information on ADHD and Down syndrome. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has a known diagnosis of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). You also indicated that within the past 6 months, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} appears to exhibit {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hyperactivity_adhd.value "==" "1"}}overactivity, restlessness, inability to sit still{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.inattention.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.impulsivity.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.distracted.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.uncooperative.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.inattention.value "==" "1"}}inattention{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.impulsivity.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.distracted.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.uncooperative.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.impulsivity.value "==" "1"}}impulsivity, acting without thinking{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.distracted.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.uncooperative.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.distracted.value "==" "1"}}being easily distracted{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.uncooperative.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.uncooperative.value "==" "1"}}uncooperative behavior, disobedience.{{/compare}} These symptoms are suggestive of unmanaged ADHD, or there may be medical causes for these symptoms. We recommend exploring this further with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "13"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<=" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.frequent_urination.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.excessive_thirst.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_diabetes.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Diabetes. Read pages 204-212 in this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to learn more about diabetes in people with Down syndrome. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Diabetes is more common in people with Down syndrome than in the general population. You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced frequent urination and excessive thirst. These may be symptoms of undiagnosed and untreated diabetes. Blood tests are necessary to establish a diagnosis. Treatments are available for those with a confirmed diagnosis. We recommend discussing this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "13"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.frequent_urination.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.excessive_thirst.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_diabetes.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Diabetes. Check out {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}this handout {{#es}}[Español] {{/es}}{{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to learn more about diabetes in children. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Diabetes is more common in people with Down syndrome than in the general population. You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced frequent urination and excessive thirst. These may be symptoms of undiagnosed and untreated diabetes. Blood tests are necessary to establish a diagnosis. Treatments are available for those with a confirmed diagnosis. We recommend discussing this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "8"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_arthritis.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_arthritis "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Down Syndrome Arthropathy. Consider talking with your physician about this condition. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Down syndrome arthropathy is an arthritis (or inflammation/swelling) of joints in children and adolescents with Down syndrome. You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_stiffness.value "==" "1"}}joint stiffness{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_swelling.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_pain.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_redness.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_swelling.value "==" "1"}}joint swelling{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_pain.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_redness.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_pain.value "==" "1"}}joint pain{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_redness.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_redness.value "==" "1"}}joint redness.{{/compare}} This may be Down syndrome arthropathy, or there may be another reason for these symptoms. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about potentially having X-rays and blood work done to establish a diagnosis. Treatment is available for those with a confirmed diagnosis.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_arthritis.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_arthritis "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Bone and joint conditions. Check out page 181-185 of this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. Also, this handout on gout {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} might be relevant. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_stiffness.value "==" "1"}}joint stiffness{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_swelling.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_pain.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_redness.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_swelling.value "==" "1"}}joint swelling{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_pain.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_redness.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_pain.value "==" "1"}}joint pain{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_redness.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_redness.value "==" "1"}}joint redness.{{/compare}} These symptoms may be caused by several different conditions that cause joint problems, including gout, osteoarthritis, or another condition causing inflammation. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} may require some blood work and some X-RAYS to come to a diagnosis. Consider discussing this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.limp.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Joint instability. More information on joint instability and Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced a new limp{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_pain.value "==" "1"}} and joint pain{{/compare}}. This may be caused by joint instability of the hip, knee, or ankles, which are common in people with Down syndrome. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about whether X-rays would be helpful for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}. Treatment and surgical options are available for those with a confirmed diagnosis.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiacd.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hirschsprung.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Chronic constipation. {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}More information on constipation and Down syndrome. {{#es}}[Español] {{/es}}{{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Eating enough fiber-containing foods can help while on a gluten-free diet{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Also, here are some medications that may help ease constipation{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has been experiencing constipation that is hard to treat{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "==" "1"}} and new accidents with stool{{/compare}}. Also, you indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has a diagnosis of celiac disease. Chronic (long-term) constipation is common in people with Down syndrome and celiac disease. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} might need an X-ray (a KUB) to assess how extensive the constipation might be. Sometimes, chronic constipation can lead to great discomfort and behavioral problems in people with Down syndrome. There are several different types of medications that may help {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} stool regularly. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about some of these options.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation2.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiacd.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hirschsprung.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Chronic constipation. {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}More information on constipation and Down syndrome{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Eating enough fiber-containing foods can help{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Also, here are some medications that may help ease constipation{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has been experiencing constipation that is hard to treat{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "==" "1"}} and new accidents with stool{{/compare}}. This may be suggestive of chronic (long-term) constipation, which is common in people with Down syndrome. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} may need an X-ray (a KUB) to assess how extensive the constipation might be. Sometimes, chronic constipation can lead to great discomfort and behavioral problems in people with Down syndrome. There are several different types of medications that may help {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} stool regularly. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about some of these options.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation2.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiacd.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Chronic constipation. More information on constipation and Down syndrome can be found on pages 141-144 in this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} and in this online resource {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Eating fiber-containing foods can be helpful{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Also, here are some medications that may help ease constipation{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has been experiencing constipation that is hard to treat{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "==" "1"}} and new accidents with stool{{/compare}}. This may be suggestive of chronic (long-term) constipation, which is common in people with Down syndrome. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} may need an X-ray (a KUB) to assess how extensive the constipation might be. Sometimes, chronic constipation can lead to great discomfort and behavioral problems in people with Down syndrome. There are several different types of medications that may help {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} stool regularly. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about some of these options.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiacd.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hirschsprung.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Chronic constipation. Consider connecting with this organization {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} for children with Hirschsprung disease. More information on constipation and Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Eating fiber-containing foods can be helpful. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Also, here are some medications that may help ease constipation. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has been experiencing constipation that is hard to treat{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "==" "1"}} and new accidents with stool{{/compare}}. Also, you indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has a diagnosis of celiac disease and Hirschsprung disease. Chronic (long-term) constipation is common in people with Down syndrome and celiac disease. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} might need an X-ray (a KUB) to assess how extensive the constipation might be. Sometimes, chronic constipation can lead to great discomfort and behavioral problems in people with Down syndrome. There are several different types of medications that may help {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} stool regularly. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about some of these options.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">" "13"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.reflux.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.gerd1.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Heartburn/Reflux. Read pages 138-140 in this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} for more information on gastroesophageal reflux disorder (GERD) in people Down syndrome. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced heartburn. This may be caused by gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), where stomach contents can sometimes flow backward into the esophagus (the tube connecting the mouth to the stomach). This can be particularly troublesome in people with Down syndrome. There are medications that may help prevent the heartburn, and there are also some things you can do on your own, such as limiting chocolate and caffeine consumption, and not eating for at least three hours before bed.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<=" "13"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.reflux.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.gerd1.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Heartburn/Reflux. Check out this handout {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} and this resource {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} for more information on gastroesophageal reflux disorder (GERD) in children. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced heartburn. This may be caused by gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), where stomach contents can sometimes flow backward into the esophagus (the tube connecting the mouth to the stomach). This can be particularly troublesome in people with Down syndrome. There are medications that may help prevent the heartburn, and there are also some things you can do on your own, such as limiting chocolate and caffeine consumption, and not eating for at least three hours before bed.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.cryptorchidism.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Undescended/Retractile testes. More information on undescended {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} or retractile {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} testes in children. {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Another resource on undescended testes{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that one of your current medical concerns for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} was testes that have not come down into the scrotum (the sac of skin underneath the penis. This may be undescended testes, meaning the testes have not come down into scrotum from the abdomen, or it may be retractile testes, meaning the testes have come down into the scrotum, but can move back and forth. If they are undescended testes, work with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider to schedule an appointment with a urologist for further consultation.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<=" "13"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_eczema.value "!=" "1"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.eczema.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Eczema (atopic dermatitis). More information on eczema and its treatment. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.eczema.value "==" "1"}}eczema{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.dry_skin.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.dry_skin.value "==" "1"}}dry skin{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "==" "1"}}itching.{{/compare}} This may be suggestive of eczema, among other things. Consider talking to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about different treatments (such as over-the-counter moisturizers) to help soften some of the symptoms of eczema.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">" "13"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_eczema.value "!=" "1"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.eczema.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Eczema (atopic dermatitis). More information on eczema and its treatment. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.eczema.value "==" "1"}}eczema{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.dry_skin.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.dry_skin.value "==" "1"}}dry skin{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "==" "1"}}itching.{{/compare}} This may be suggestive of eczema, among other things. Consider talking to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about different treatments (such as over-the-counter moisturizers) to help soften some of the symptoms of eczema.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.dry_skin.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Dry skin (xerosis). More information and treatment options {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} for dry skin in people with Down syndrome. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.dry_skin.value "==" "1"}}dry skin{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "==" "1"}} and {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "==" "1"}}itching.{{/compare}} This may be suggestive of dry skin (xerosis), among other things. Dry skin is very common in people with Down syndrome. Consider talking to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about different treatments (such as over-the-counter moisturizers).
{{/if}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidradenitis.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_hidraedenitis.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Skin boils (Hidradenitis suppurativa). Here is a handout {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. Also, read pages 71-73 of this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced skin boils under armpits and groins. This is a common, but treatable, skin condition in people with Down syndrome. Skin boils that cause scarring are called hidradenitis suppurativa. Check out the resources above for more information. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about this. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} may also need to see a dermatologist for more advanced treatment, if necessary.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hair_loss.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_hairloss.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Alopecia areata (hair loss). More information on alopecia areata. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced hair loss. There can be many different causes of hair loss, but one common cause to consider is alopecia areata, an autoimmune condition (caused by your own body’s immune cells backfiring) that causes hair to fall out for no apparent reason. Treatment is available for those with a confirmed diagnosis, but you should consider discussing this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider and talking about whether or not a dermatology referral is necessary.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.acne.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Acne. Here is a handout {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}, and another one {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that one of your current medical concerns for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} is acne. Acne can certainly cause a lot of stress and self-consciousness. Consider discussing this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider and talking about whether or not a dermatology referral would be helpful.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.vitiligo.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_vitiligo.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Vitiligo. Information and treatment options for vitiligo. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced areas of skin that have turned white or lost their color. There may be a few different reasons for this, but one condition that is common in people with Down syndrome is vitiligo, which is caused by the body’s own immune cells backfiring (autoimmune). Treatments are available for those with a confirmed diagnosis. Consider discussing this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.onychomycosis_current.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Toenail fungus. More information on fungal nail infections. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced toenails that have turned yellow, white or brown, or changed shape. This may be suggestive of toenail fungus (medically known as onychomycosis), which is common in people with Down syndrome. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about this and possible treatment. After it is treated and has resolved, one fun way of preventing future toenail fungal infections is getting regular pedicures at a salon with dedication to cleanliness!
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">" "13"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.seasonal_allergies.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Seasonal allergies. Read pages 83-85 in this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} for information and treatment options on seasonal allergies in people with Down syndrome. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that seasonal allergies is one of your current medical concerns for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}. These allergies can be common in people with Down syndrome. A range of over-the-counter medications may help lessen some of these symptoms. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about your options.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<=" "13"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.seasonal_allergies.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Seasonal allergies. Check out {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}this handout {{#es}}[Español] {{/es}}{{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} for seasonal allergies in children with Down syndrome. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that seasonal allergies is one of your current medical concerns for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}. These allergies can be common in people with Down syndrome. A range of over-the-counter medications may help lessen some of these symptoms. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about your options.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.irregular_menstruation.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.menstrual_cramps.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Menstrual (period) complaints. Read chapter 5, pages 96-102 in this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to learn more about some treatment options for menstrual complaints in women with Down syndrome. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.irregular_menstruation.value "==" "1"}}irregular periods{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.menstrual_cramps.value "==" "1"}} and {{/compare}}{{/compare}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.menstrual_cramps.value "==" "1"}}severe cramps{{/compare}}. Treatments are available for menstrual complaints; talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about these issues and the different treatment options that may be available.
{{/if}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.delayed_puberty.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Growth Hormone Deficiency. If {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} is less than the 3% for height on the Down syndrome specific growth curves {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}, consider asking {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} primary provider about growth hormone deficiency {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that one of your current medical concerns is that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} is of a short stature compared with other children with Down syndrome {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} age.

{{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.property_destruction.value "==" "1"}}property destruction{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.forgetful.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.stereotypic_movements.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.irritable.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.situation_fear.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.chews_parts.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.forgetful.value "==" "1"}}forgetfulness{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.stereotypic_movements.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.irritable.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.situation_fear.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.chews_parts.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.stereotypic_movements.value "==" "1"}}stereotypic motor movements{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.irritable.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.situation_fear.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.chews_parts.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.irritable.value "==" "1"}}irritability{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.situation_fear.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.chews_parts.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.situation_fear.value "==" "1"}}fear of particular situations{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.chews_parts.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.chews_parts.value "==" "1"}}chewing body parts{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "==" "1"}}general agitation.{{/compare}} These symptoms may be suggestive of Alzheimer disease, or they may be suggestive of untreated anxiety, depression, or other medical issues (such as hypothyroidism). It will be important for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s primary provider to rule out these other causes. Alzheimer disease is a form of dementia that is common in adults with Down syndrome. Some research shows that up to 10 of every 100 people with Down syndrome have Alzheimer disease by age 50; 36 of 100 by age 60; and 55 of 100 by age 70. It is important to recognize the signs and symptoms of dementia as early as possible in order to make best use of resources, supports, and possibly medications.
{{/compare}}

Health and Wellness Resources for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}

Here are some specific resources based on your requests.

{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.audio_12m.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hearing_loss.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_hearing.value "!=" "1"}}

Hearing loss concerns. More information on hearing loss and Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Evaluation and treatment options [video]. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Since {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has had a hearing test within the last year, you might find this handout and webinar helpful because you indicated that you still had some concerns about hearing loss. If you learn something new, you might consider discussing this handout and webinar with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}'s provider.

Vision concerns. More information on vision changes and Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Evaluation and treatment options [video]. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Since {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has had an eye exam within the last two years, you might find this handout helpful because you indicated that you still had some concerns about vision. Consider asking your primary care doctor if a referral to an eye doctor would be helpful.
{{/if}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.ophtho_1y.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.ophtho_2y.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.ophtho_3y.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.ophtho_2yadult.value "1") )}} {{#if (and (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.concerns_about_vision.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.keratoconus.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Keratoconus. More information on keratoconus and Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} A video on corneal cross-linking, a developing treatment option [video]. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} Since you indicated that you have some concerns about vision and {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has a history of keratoconus, you might find this handout helpful. If by reading this handout, you learn something new, you might consider printing it out and discussing with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider.
{{/if}} {{/if}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.ophtho_1y.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.ophtho_2y.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.ophtho_3y.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.ophtho_2yadult.value "1") )}} {{#if (and (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.concerns_about_vision.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.cataracts.value "1") )}}

{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Nystagmus. More information on nystagmus. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that you have some concerns about {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} having involuntary eye movements. This may be suggestive of a condition called “nystagmus.” You should discuss this with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s doctor, and you might find this handout to be helpful.
{{/if}} {{/if}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiac_test.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiacd.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.gluten_free.value "==" "2"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_celiac1 "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_celiac2 "1") )}}

easily or for no reason{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.lose_skills.value "==" "1"}}loss of previously learned skills.{{/compare}} You also indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has a diagnosis of celiac disease but is not on a gluten-free diet. This may be causing {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} to experience some of these symptoms. You should talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s doctor about the benefits of a gluten-free diet.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiac_test.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiac_time.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiacd.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.gluten_free.value "==" "1"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_celiac1 "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_celiac2 "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Gluten-free foods. Brief handout {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} and more information on gluten-free foods {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. Also, you can find a wealth of resources from CeliacNow {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation.value "==" "1"}}constipation that is learned skills.{{/compare}} You also indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has a diagnosis of celiac disease, is on a gluten-free diet, and has had testing for celiac disease done within {{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Sleep apnea. Successfully treating sleep apnea can be hard. Here is a handout that highlights several treatment options that might be appropriate for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} If a sleeping mask is indicated, here are some tips for success {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "18"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "4"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.cpap.value "==" "1"}} Also, here is a handout that talks about using a breathing mask for sleep apnea for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.cpap.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tonsils.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.adenoids.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.cranio_surge.value "1"))}} and has tried {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.cpap.value "==" "1"}}a sleep mask (also known as CPAP or BiPAP){{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.tonsils.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.adenoids.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.cranio_surge.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.tonsils.value "==" "1"}}having tonsils removed{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.adenoids.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.cranio_surge.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.adenoids.value "==" "1"}}having adenoids removed{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.cranio_surge.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.cranio_surge.value "==" "1"}}craniofacial surgery to address sleep apnea.{{/compare}} {{else}}.{{/if}} {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has also had a sleep study within the past 12 months. {{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Sleep apnea. Successfully treating sleep apnea can be hard. Here is a handout that highlights several treatment options that might be appropriate for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} If a sleeping mask is indicated, here are some tips for success {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea but has not tried any treatments for it. {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.polysom_time.value "==" "1"}}Also, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has had a sleep study within the past 12 months. {{/compare}} Within the past month, you reported that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.heshe}} has also been experiencing symptoms such as {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.snore.value "==" "1"}}snoring{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.gasp_sleep.value "1") (eq should consider printing and sharing with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider. {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.polysom_time.value "==" "0"}}Since it has been at least 12 months since {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}‘s last sleep study, consider discussing a repeat sleep study with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider to see if the apnea has gotten any worse.{{/compare}}
{{/if}} {{/if}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.talk_self.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "18"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Self-talk. Check out this resource {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} about self-talk in adults with Down syndrome. Also check out chapter 8 in this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to see if it fits with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s behavior. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past 6 months {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced talking to self. Self talk is a normal way for adults with Down syndrome to process their world. If the self talk becomes negative or seems upsetting to the individual, consider discussing this with your provider.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.talk_self.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "18"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Self-talk. Check out this resource {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} about self-talk in people with Down syndrome. While it happens to be about adults with Down syndrome, the information is pertinent to all ages. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past 6 months {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced talking to self. Self talk is a normal way for people with Down syndrome to process their world. If the self talk becomes negative or seems upsetting to the individual, consider discussing this with your provider.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.groove.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "13"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_autism.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Down syndrome “groove.” Check out this resource {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} and chapter 9 in this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} about “the groove” in people with Down syndrome. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past 6 months {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced tendency toward repetitive behaviors, rigitidy, or sameness. Dr. Dennis McGuire, one of the leading psychologists for people with Down syndrome, summarizes in the above that “people with Down syndrome need sameness, repetition, and order in their lives. We call this tendency the “groove” because thoughts and actions of people tend to follow fairly well-worn paths, or grooves. Grooves can either be helpful or harmful depending on the situation. Discuss any of your concerns with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.temper_meltdowns_irritability.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "3"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "13"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.throws_objects.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hits_self.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.bites_self.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.injures_self.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.bangs_head.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.hits_others.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.mood_swings.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.aggression.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.property_destruction.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.forgetful.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.stereotypic_movements.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Chronic constipation. {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}More information on constipation and Down syndrome{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Eating enough fiber-containing foods can help{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Also, here are some medications that may help ease constipation{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has constipation that is hard to treat and has a history of chronic constipation.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation2.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiacd.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hirschsprung.value "==" "1"}}

Chronic constipation. More information on constipation and Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Eating enough fiber-containing foods can help. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Also, here are some medications that may help ease constipation. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has constipation that is hard to treat and has a history of chronic constipation.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiacd.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hirschsprung.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Chronic constipation. Consider connecting with this organization {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} for children with Hirschsprung disease. {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}More information on constipation and Down syndrome{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Eating enough fiber-containing foods can help{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}Also, here are some medications that may help ease constipation{{#es}} [Español]{{/es}}. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has been experiencing constipation that is hard to treat and also has a past medical history of Hirschsprung disease. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} might need an X-ray (a KUB) to assess how extensive the constipation might be. Sometimes, chronic constipation can lead to great discomfort and behavioral problems in people with Down syndrome. There are several different types of medications that may help {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} stool regularly. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about some of these options.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.toilet_training.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Toilet training tips for children with Down syndrome. Here is a great webinar [video] with step-by-step tips {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} and an online resource with visual prompts {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that one of your current medical concerns for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} is toilet training.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.ocp.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Questions about Oral-Contraceptive Pills (OCPs). Read chapter 5, pages 98-102 in this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to learn more about OCP use and menstruation. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that you and {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} had questions about OCP use. OCPs are often safely prescribed for adolescents and adult women with Down syndrome, especially to treat menstrual complaints (such as menstrual cramps). However, using OCPs may carry a slightly increased risk of blood clots (known as thrombosis). Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about any questions or concerns you may have.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.sex_active.value "==" "1"}}

{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.masturbation.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_gender.value "==" "O"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Concerns about Masturbation. This book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} is great for you, the caregiver, especially chapter 6. Consider this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} or this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} had questions or concerns about masturbation.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.gum_problems.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.flossing.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.brushing.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.cavities.value "1") )}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.dentist.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Dental issues. Regular dental care is important for all people with Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Here is a webinar [video] {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} on common dental issues for people with Down syndrome. Please see this handout for how to prepare for a dental visit. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} And, a book for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} to read as {{pcori_dsp_interventi.heshe}} prepares for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} visit. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} And, here is a webinar [video] {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} in case orthodontic care is needed. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that within the past month, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.gum_problems.value "==" "1"}}gum problems{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.flossing.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.brushing.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.cavities.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.flossing.value "==" "1"}}difficulty flossing{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.brushing.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.cavities.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.brushing.value "==" "1"}}difficulty brushing{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.cavities.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.cavities.value "==" "1"}}cavities.{{/compare}}
{{/compare}} {{/if}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.weight_gain.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Weight management. In general, people with Down syndrome have slower metabolisms, which can make it hard to lose weight. Here is a handout {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} with some more information on weight management in Down syndrome. Also, consider reading this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that one of your current medical concerns for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} is weight gain{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_obesity.value "==" "1"}}, and that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has a past medical history of obesity or being overweight{{/compare}}.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_tmpd.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "6"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

CBCs in Transient Myeloproliferative Disorder (TMD). Here is a handout {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} that contains information about TMD and the general recommendation on how often {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} should have CBCs (Complete Blood Counts, looking at blood cells) with a past diagnosis of TMD. Even after TMD has resolved, a CBC is needed every 3 months until 3 years of age, and then every 6 months until 6 years of age. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has a past medical history of transient myeloproliferative disorder. Talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} ’s provider about whether or not {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} is getting the routine CBCs as often as recommended.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "40"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_dementia.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_dementiasx "==" "0"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Dementia/Alzheimer disease. More information on Alzheimer disease and Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Also, check out chapter 20 of this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. Also, here is a free online book about aging and Down syndrome. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} More information on the Alzheimer’s Disease Association. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} And, check out this store with products for people with Alzheimer disease {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated on your current medical and mental health concerns that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} already has a diagnosis of dementia.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "40"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_dementia.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_dementiasx "==" "1"}}

{{/compare}}

Nutrition Recommendations for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}

People with Down syndrome, in general, have slower metabolism. Focusing on healthy eating, at all ages, is important. Sometimes, making just a few tweaks in one’s diet can go a long way. Based on your responses, here are some suggestions:

{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.sugar.value "==" "2"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Ask {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s doctor if {{pcori_dsp_interventi.heshe}} should cut back on sugar-sweetened drinks. Here is more information. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} drinks more juice, soda, or other sweetened beverage than recommended. The handout above illustrates the amount of sugar in popular drinks including 100% juice and provides low-calorie alternatives. Persons over the age of 2 should limit drinks to water, flavored seltzer, and reduced fat or skim milk. For children between 1 and 2 years of age, limit drinks to water and 2-3 cups of whole milk per day.
{{/compare}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.calcium.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.calcium.value "2") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Ask {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s doctor if {{pcori_dsp_interventi.heshe}} should have more calcium in the diet. This handout {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} details daily calcium needs based on age, and foods you can offer to ensure that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} is meeting {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} needs. Also, individuals should take between 400 - 1000 international units of Vitamin D a day based on their age, which can be consumed through food, pill, or supplement. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} does not meet {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} daily calcium needs.
{{/if}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.snack_habits.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.snack_habits.value "2") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.snack_habits.value "4") )}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "18"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Healthier snacking. This handout {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} is a great visual guide to encourage healthy snack choices. Here are some options for healthy, low-calorie snacks. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} likes sweets or crunchy foods for snacks.
{{/compare}} {{/if}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.snack_habits.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.snack_habits.value "2") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.snack_habits.value "4") )}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "18"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Healthier snacking. This handout {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} is a great visual guide to encourage healthy snack choices. Here are some options for healthy, low-calorie snacks. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Also, check this out {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} for more information on setting up a healthy snack time. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} likes sweets or crunchy foods for snacks.
{{/compare}} {{/if}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.servings.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Ask {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s doctor about increasing fruit and vegetables in {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s diet. Here are 20 ways to help encourage fruit and vegetable intake. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Here is a handout with some tips {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to increase fiber in {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} diet. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} is not meeting {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} daily fruit and vegetable goal. It is also possible that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.heshe}} is also not meeting {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} fiber needs as a result.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.beh4.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "6"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has sensory preferences. This can be due to selective eating or sensory preferences. This handout {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} is recommended to learn more about steps you can take to help {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} increase number of foods that are accepted. If this is interfering with mealtimes on a daily basis, talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about considering a referral to a feeding therapist (a specialized Speech and Language Pathologist). {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} experiences rigid sensory preferences (or picky eating).
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.beh4.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_autism.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "6"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "18"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has rigid sensory preferences. This can be due to selective eating or sensory preferences. This handout {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} is recommended to learn more about steps you can take to help {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} increase number of foods that are accepted. If this is interfering with mealtimes on a daily basis, talk to {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about considering a referral to a feeding therapist (a specialized Speech and Language Pathologist). {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} experiences rigid sensory preferences (or picky eating) and also autism spectrum disorder.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.beh5.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Ask {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about a possible referral to a registered dietitian or therapist to help with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s refusal to eat. Also, {{#en}}{{/en}}{{#es}}{{/es}}here is a handout {{#es}}[Español] {{/es}}{{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} with some tips that may help. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} sometimes demonstrates a refusal to eat.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.beh6.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Ask {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s provider about a possible referral to a registered dietitian or therapist {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to help with {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s binge eating. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} sometimes demonstrates binge eating.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.beh7.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "18"}}

Life Skills Suggestions for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}

One step at a time, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} can become increasingly more independent. Based on your responses, here are some specific resources to help achieve those life skills that you wanted {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} to work on next.

For more information on transitions related topics, please visit this excellent “got transitions” website, or this resource specific website, or this book.

Life Skills Suggestions for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}

One step at a time, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} can become increasingly more independent. Based on your responses, here are some specific resources to help achieve those life skills that you wanted {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} to work on next.

For more information on transitions related topics, please visit this excellent “got transitions” website, or this resource specific website, or this book.

{{/if}}{{/if}}{{/if}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.gen_md_talk.value "2") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.gen_sx_describe.value "2") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.gen_meds_reason.value "2") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.gen_meds_take.value "2") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.gen_rx.value "2") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.well_foods.value "2") )}}

Education/Therapy Resources for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}

Each year, researchers are better understanding how people with Down syndrome learn. Based on your requests, here are some resources for you to consider for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}.

{{/if}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.sign_language.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Using sign language to communicate. Many parents have found this video series to be helpful. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} And, here's why. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.speech_comm.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "5"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

{{else}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<=" "13"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

{{else}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<=" "17"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

{{else}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.vocation.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Vocational skill/employment opportunities. Click here for an overview of employment options {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. Also, check out the resources of the Your Next Star campaign {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}, including resources for applicants {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} and employers {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. Here are more resources and success stories from #DSWORKS® {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}. For more information on employment, check out this website {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} and this handout {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}}.
{{/compare}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.classroom_type.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.inclusion.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.aba_therapy.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

{{/compare}}

Information and Resources for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}'s Caregiver

Here are some specific resources based on your requests.

{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.adrc.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Aging and Disability Resource Consortia (ADRC). ADRCs offer coordinated systems of information and access to long-term services and supports regardless of disability, age, or income, starting at age 21. Since ADRCs vary from state to state, we recommend that you use Google to search for the ADRC in your state, by entering “ADRC” and the name of your state, to find your local organization. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You requested more information on ADRC (Aging and Disability Resource Consortia).
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.arc.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

The Arc. More information on their webpage. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Find your local Arc chapter. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You requested more information on the Arc.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.bestbuds.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Best Buddies. More information on their webpage. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} Find programs in your state. {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

{{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}} You requested more information on Best Buddies.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.dsconnect.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

DS-Connect®. Consider registering {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} at DS-Connect {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} to connect with researchers and healthcare providers. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}

Special Needs Trust/ABLE Accounts. Check out this website {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} or this book {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} for more information on setting up a special needs financial planning. Some states enable parents and caregivers to set up an ABLE account. Learn more about ABLE accounts here {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} and check out this website {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} for a comparison of state ABLE accounts. Also, here {{#i18n "linkout"}}{{/i18n}} you can see a chart comparing ABLE accounts and third-party special needs trusts and also read up on some pros and cons of ABLE accounts. {{#i18n "why"}}{{/i18n}}
