Attention-Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver marked that within the past 6 months of completing our intake, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} appears to exhibit {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hyperactivity_adhd.value "==" "1"}}overactivity, restlessness, inability to sit still{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.inattention.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.impulsivity.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.distracted.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.uncooperative.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.inattention.value "==" "1"}}inattention{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.impulsivity.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.distracted.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.uncooperative.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.impulsivity.value "==" "1"}}impulsivity, acting without thinking{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.distracted.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.uncooperative.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.distracted.value "==" "1"}}being easily distracted{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.uncooperative.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.uncooperative.value "==" "1"}}uncooperative behavior, disobedience.{{/compare}} ADHD occurs with an increased frequency in people with Down syndrome. Psychopharmacology may be considered if possible medical causes can be treated and eliminated.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<=" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.frequent_urination.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.excessive_thirst.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_diabetes.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Diabetes mellitus (DM). Studies indicate that type 1 DM might be more common in people with Down syndrome than in the general population. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that within the past month of completing our intake, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} experienced frequent urination and excessive thirst.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "8"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_arthritis.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_arthritis "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Down Syndrome Arthropathy. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that within the past month of completing our intake, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_stiffness.value "==" "1"}}joint stiffness{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_swelling.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_pain.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_redness.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_swelling.value "==" "1"}}joint swelling{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_pain.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_redness.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_pain.value "==" "1"}}joint pain{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_redness.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_redness.value "==" "1"}}joint redness.{{/compare}} Down syndrome arthropathy is a diagnosis of exclusion; when suspected, a full-work up for other causes of arthritis, including autoimmune antibody titers and X-rays of joints, should be pursued, Treatment can begin with NSAIDs; if this fails to alleviate symptoms, a referral to rheumatology may be considered.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_arthritis.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_arthritis "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Arthropathies. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that within the past month of completing our intake, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_stiffness.value "==" "1"}}joint stiffness{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_swelling.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_pain.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_redness.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_swelling.value "==" "1"}}joint swelling{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_pain.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_redness.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_pain.value "==" "1"}}joint pain{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_redness.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_redness.value "==" "1"}}joint redness.{{/compare}} Gout and osteoarthritis are all common in people with Down syndrome, and a full standard work up should be pursued in patients presenting with symptoms of joint pathology, including a workup for other connective tissue disorders.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.limp.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Joint instability. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that within the past month of completing our intake, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced a new limp{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.joint_pain.value "==" "1"}} and joint pain{{/compare}}. Joint instability of the hips, knees, and ankles are common in people with Down syndrome. We would recommend considering X-rays if there is recurrent pain or instability. If normal, follow-up with physical therapy is recommended.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation2.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiacd.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hirschsprung.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Chronic constipation. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that within the past month of completing our intake, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} experienced constipation that is hard to treat{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "==" "1"}} and new accidents with stool{{/compare}}. Chronic constipation is a common feature in patients with Down syndrome and celiac disease and can lead to behavioral dysregulation if left untreated. Consider obtaining a KUB and trying medication to alleviate the constipation, if needed.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation2.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiacd.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hirschsprung.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Chronic constipation. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that within the past month of completing our intake, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} experienced constipation that is hard to treat{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "==" "1"}} and new accidents with stool{{/compare}}. Chronic constipation is a common feature in patients with Down syndrome, and can lead to behavioral issues if left untreated. Consider obtaining a KUB and trying medication to alleviate the constipation if needed.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age ">=" "21"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.constipation2.value "!=" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.celiacd.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Chronic constipation. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that within the past month of completing our intake, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} experienced constipation that is hard to treat{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.incontinence_stool.value "==" "1"}} and new accidents with stool{{/compare}}. Chronic constipation is a common feature in patients with Down syndrome and can lead to behavioral issues if left untreated. Consider obtaining a KUB and trying medication to alleviate the constipation if needed.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.reflux.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.gerd1.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

GERD. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that within the past month of completing our intake, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} experienced heartburn. GERD can be particularly severe in patients with Down syndrome. PPIs or H2-antagonists may be considered to alleviate the reflux. In severe cases, a fundoplication procedure may be necessary.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.cryptorchidism.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Cryptorchidism/Retractile Testes. One of {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver’s current medical concerns was testes that have not come down into the scrotum. Cryptorchidism can occur in 14 - 27% of males with Down syndrome, but retractile testes can also occur. Of note, testicular cancer is also more common in males with Down syndrome, independent of cryptorchidism. We would recommend a urological referral to consider surgically resolving the undescended testes as soon as possible.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_eczema.value "!=" "1"}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.eczema.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Atopic dermatitis. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that within the past month of completing our intake, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.eczema.value "==" "1"}}eczema{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.dry_skin.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "1") )}}, {{else}}.{{/if}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.dry_skin.value "==" "1"}}dry skin{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "==" "1"}}itching.{{/compare}} This may be suggestive of eczema, which can be common in people with Down syndrome. Pursue the same treatment options that you would use in the typically developing population.
{{/if}} {{/compare}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.dry_skin.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Dry Skin/Xerosis. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that within the past month of completing our intake, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.dry_skin.value "==" "1"}}dry skin{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "==" "1"}} and {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.itching.value "==" "1"}}itching.{{/compare}} This may be suggestive of xerosis, which can be common in people with Down syndrome. Pursue the same treatment options that you would use in the typically developing population.
{{/if}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidradenitis.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_hidraedenitis.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Hidradenitis suppurativa. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that within the past month of completing our intake, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced skin boils under armpits and groins. The full range of skin boils (folliculitis, furuncles, carbuncles, and hidradenitis suppurativa) have an increased incidence in people with Down syndrome. Consider a dermatology referral, if needed.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hair_loss.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_hairloss.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Alopecia areata. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that within the past month of completing our intake, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced hair loss. Alopecia areata, like other autoimmune conditions, has an increased incidence in people with Down syndrome. Consider a dermatological referral if alopecia areata appears to be the likely cause of the hair loss, as treatment options are available.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.acne.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Acne. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that acne is one of their current medical concerns for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}. Consider discussing different treatment options and pursuing a dermatology referral, if necessary. Treatment options are the same for persons with Down syndrome.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.vitiligo.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pmh_vitiligo.value "!=" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Vitiligo. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that within the past month of completing our intake, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced areas of skin that have turned white or lost their color. While a physical exam and further exploration is necessary to eliminate other causes of discolored skin, it is worth noting that vitiligo is of an increased incidence in people with Down syndrome and should be considered in the differential.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.onychomycosis_current.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Onychomycosis. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that within the past month of completing our intake, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced toenails that have turned yellow, white or brown, or changed shape. This may be indicative of onychomycosis which is commonly seen in patients with Down syndrome. Regular clinical examination of the toenails of people with Down syndrome is encouraged.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.seasonal_allergies.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Seasonal allergies. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that within the past month of completing our intake, seasonal allergies was one of their current medical concerns for {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}. We recommended discussing with you some medications to help alleviate some of these symptoms.
{{/compare}} {{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.irregular_menstruation.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.menstrual_cramps.value "1") )}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Menstrual complaints. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}'s caregiver indicated that within the past month of completing our intake {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has experienced {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.irregular_menstruation.value "==" "1"}}irregular periods{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.menstrual_cramps.value "==" "1"}} and {{/compare}}{{/compare}}{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.menstrual_cramps.value "==" "1"}}severe cramps{{/compare}}. Menstrual complaints such as primary dysmenorrhea and metorrhagia can occur in women and girls with Down syndrome, although indicators of menstrual pain may be more subtle (for example, reduction in activity levels, changes in behavior while menstruating, etc.). Treatment is the same as in the general population, although it is worth considering that OCP use may carry a slightly increased risk of thromboembolism in women with Down syndrome.
{{/if}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.delayed_puberty.value "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Growth Hormone Deficiency. There is evidence that some people with Down syndrome have low circulating levels of IGF-1 and a diminished secretion of GH. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} has a short stature compared with other children with Down syndrome {{pcori_dsp_interventi.hishertheir}} age. If {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}} is < 3% for height on the new Down syndrome-specific growth curves, we recommend pursuing a standard workup for possible growth hormone deficiency. Treatment is only warranted if true growth hormone deficiency exists.
{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.torticollis.value "==" "1"}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.pt_age "<" "2"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Torticollis (Neck tilt). {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}'s caregiver indicated that within the past month of completing our intake, {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s head stays tilted to one side. Individuals with DS have an increased risk of torticollis due to their hypotonia. This is often manageable with additional PT therapy. Resources were provided to caregivers.
{{/compare}} {{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.hidden_dementia "==" "1"}}
{{#i18n "checkmark"}}{{/i18n}}

Alzheimer disease. Adults with Down syndrome above the age of 35 have a high incidence of Alzheimer disease, ranging from 50-75%. {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}’s caregiver indicated that pcori_dsp_interventi.chews_parts.value "==" "1"}}chewing body parts{{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "==" "1"}}, {{else}}.{{/compare}}{{/compare}} {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.agitation.value "==" "1"}}general agitation.{{/compare}} While Alzheimer disease is suspected, it is important to exclude anxiety, depression, and other medical causes (e.g., obstructive sleep apnea and hypothyroidism), which can also present with these same symptoms. Early recognition of signs and symptoms of dementia and appropriate management can help slow cognitive decline; although, of note, traditional medications may not be as effective in adults with Down syndrome in the general population with Alzheimer disease.
{{/compare}}

●

Informational handout to discuss with you on different therapeutic approaches for obstructive sleep apnea to treat {{pcori_dsp_interventi.first_name}}'s ongoing symptoms such as {{#compare pcori_dsp_interventi.snore.value "==" "1"}}snoring{{#if (or (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.gasp_sleep.value "1") (eq pcori_dsp_interventi.mouth_open.value "1") (eq
